So I knew a fisherman who told me whales would rub against the bottom of the boat all the time (since the bottom of the boat had pointy edges). They believed it was trying to scrape off the whale lice and and barnacles on their body.  They decided one day to use a barnacle scraper and rake on the whale and they would stop coming around wanting to be scratched. He said they absolutely loved having the lice and barnacles  scraped off of them. Judging by what he told me, lice and barnacles are parasites and feel great relief once the parasites have been removed!

The most disturbing thing about this story: It's not the first time I'm familiar with where evolutionary biologists have used "lice" to infer divergence between two closely related species.

We've previously used human hair & pubic lice to estimate when our ancestors split off from chimpanzees & gorillas (though this is slightly confusing). Our hair lice, which have hooked feet designed to hold on to the round follicles on our scalp, face & chest are closely related to chimpanzee lice, while our pubic lice (adapted to grasp flatter pubic hair) are related to gorillas.
This is thought to be either due to environmental transfer, or from human predation.

Genetic examination of these little parasites shows that the pubic lice split off some 3.3 million years ago, while scalp & body hair lice are perhaps only a few hundred thousand.

In fact, almost all of wild animals have parasites like lice living on their body. It is not because these parasites are beneficial to the animals, but because the animals don't have any effective methods to get rid of them.
Even we, well groomed humans have mites on our skin and face right now. We hate them but we can't do much about it.

Journal Entry: "Teeniweenivki Skuttlebut, attorney. Proud citizen of the Left Brow Nation. Year 45.

Just completed an execution. It sickens me to see another Cyamid be snuffed out by society. But what truly haunts me is what he was trying to tell us before his execution. The LBN Council apparently agreed, as they demanded his immediate silence and unannounced execution. In the days leading to his captivity he continually spouted hysterical nonsense about how our world was not the only one. How our largely unexplored planet is, in fact, only one of countless others. And that our planet is, truthfully, a behemoth of insatiable bloodlust that consumes creatures not unlike ourselves regularly. Millions at a time swallowed at once by it's bottomless maw. As do all the other similar planets. I shudder at the thought. But as horrifying as that revelation would be on its own. His final words, spoken with the desperate sincerity of a man finally choosing to preserve the truth over his own life, were what made everyone's antennae curl."

"As ruthless as it is, our planet and it's kin are the gentler souls. There are entities far more dangerous that hunt them without mercy. Be grateful to our monster. For it is the only one we have."
